review.title: Sequential Diagnosis by Abstraction
review.abstract: When a system behaves abnormally, sequential diagnosis takes a sequence of measurements of the system until the faults causing the abnormality are identified, and the goal is to reduce the diagnostic cost, defined here as the number of measurements. To propose measurement points, previous work employs a heuristic based on reducing the entropy over a computed set of diagnoses. This approach generally has good performance in terms of diagnostic cost, but can fail to diagnose large systems when the set of diagnoses is too large. Focusing on a smaller set of probable diagnoses scales the approach but generally leads to increased average diagnostic costs. In this paper, we propose a new diagnostic framework employing four new techniques, which scales to much larger systems with good performance in terms of diagnostic cost. First, we propose a new heuristic for measurement point selection that can be computed efficiently, without requiring the set of diagnoses, once the system is modeled as a Bayesian network and compiled into a logical form known as d-DNNF. Second, we extend hierarchical diagnosis, a technique based on system abstraction from our previous work, to handle probabilities so that it can be applied to sequential diagnosis to allow larger systems to be diagnosed. Third, for the largest systems where even hierarchical diagnosis fails, we propose a novel method that converts the system into one that has a smaller abstraction and whose diagnoses form a superset of those of the original system; the new system can then be diagnosed and the result mapped back to the original system. Finally, we propose a novel cost estimation function which can be used to choose an abstraction of the system that is more likely to provide optimal average cost. Experiments with ISCAS-85 benchmark circuits indicate that our approach scales to all circuits in the suite except one that has a flat structure not susceptible to useful abstraction.

sections.heading: 4.2 Hierarchical Approach
sections.text: The basic idea is that assembling the system model in d-DNNF will be more efficient and scalable if the number of system components is reduced, which can be achieved by abstraction, where subsystems, so-called cones, are treated as individual components. An example of a cone is shown in Figure 1. The goal is to use a single health variable and failure probability for the entire cone, which significantly reduces the size of the coding and the difficulty of assembling it. Once a cone is identified as faulty in the top-level diagnosis, it can be compiled and diagnosed in a recursive way.We will now give a formal definition of the abstraction from our previous work:

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Abstraction of System
sections.text: The abstraction is based on the structural dominators (Kirkland & Mercer, 1987) of a system. A component X dominates a component Y or X is called a dominator of Y, if any path from Y to any output of system X. A cone corresponds exactly to the set of components dominated by a component. A cone can contain additional cones that lead to a hierarchy of cones. A system can be abstracted by treating all the maximum cones in it as black boxes (a maximum cone is one that is either not contained in any other cone or contained in exactly one other cone that represents the entire system). In our example, cone A can be treated as a virtual gate with two inputs {P, D} and output A. The abstraction of a system can be formally defined as: definition 1 (abstraction of the system).

sections.heading: 5. Component Cloning
sections.text: In the previous section, we proposed an abstraction-based approach to sequential diagnosis that reduces the complexity of composition and diagnosis by reducing the number of system components to be diagnosed. We now go a step further and aim to manage systems that are so large that they remain insoluble even after abstraction, as is the case for the largest circuits in the ISCAS 85 benchmark suit.Our solution is a novel method that systematically modifies the structure of a system to reduce the size of its abstraction. In particular, we choose a component G with parents P (a component X is a parent of a component Y, and Y is a child of X, if the output of Y is an input of X) that is not part of a connection and therefore cannot be strayed away.

sections.heading: 5.1 Choices in Component Cloning
sections.text: There are two possibilities when cloning components: What components do we clone, and how many clones do we create, and how do the parents share them? Since the goal of cloning is to reduce the abstraction size, it is clear that we only want to clone those components that are in the abstraction (i.e., not within cones), among which cloning the root of a cone cannot reduce the abstraction size, since it destroys the existing cone by reintroducing some of the components within the cone into the abstraction. For example, cloning D according to Figure 4 will produce a circuit in which D and its clone are gone, but B will no longer be dominated by D, and thus the last candidates for cloning will be reintroduced into the abstraction.

sections.heading: 5.2 Diagnosis with Component Cloning
sections.text: The new system is functionally equivalent to the original and has a smaller abstraction, but is not equivalent to the original for diagnostic reasons. As the new model allows a component and its clones to fail independently, it is a loosening of the original model, since the diagnoses of the new system constitute a superset of diagnoses of the original. Specifically, any diagnosis of the new system that assigns a component the same state of health, and its clones for all components correspond to a diagnosis of the original system; other diagnoses are inauthentic and must be ignored. The core diagnostic process specified in Algorithm 2 is still applicable to the new system, requiring only two minor modifications. First, the incorrect diagnoses are (implicitly) filtered out, assuming that the same state of health is useless for all clones (including the original) of a component once the state of health of one of these components is known.

sections.heading: 9. Conclusion
sections.text: We introduced a new sequential diagnostic system called sda, which uses four new structure-based techniques to scale diagnosis to larger systems. Specifically, it uses heuristics for measurement selection, which can be efficiently calculated from the system's d-DNNF compilation. To diagnose larger systems, it automatically calculates a structural abstraction of the system and performs a hierarchical diagnosis. It then uses a structure-based technique to further reduce the abstraction size of the system, which scales the diagnosis to the largest benchmark systems. Finally, it can automatically select an abstraction of the system that leads to optimal average costs.

Following de Kleer and Williams (1987) we assume that all measurements have unit cost. Hence the objective is to reach a goal state in the fewest measurements possible. The classical gde framework, on receiving an abnormal observation Xo = xo, considers the Shannon’s entropy of the probability distribution over a set of computed diagnoses, which is either the set of minimum-cardinality diagnoses or a set of probable/leading diagnoses. It proposes to measure a variable X whose value will reduce that entropy the most, on average. The idea is that the probability distribution over the diagnoses reflects the uncertainty over the actual faults, and the entropy captures the amount of this uncertainty. After a measurement is taken the entropy is updated by updating the posterior probabilities of the diagnoses, potentially reducing some of them to 0. The results reported by de Kleer et al. (1992) involving single-fault cases for ISCAS-85 circuits indicate that this method leads to measurement costs close to those of optimal policies.

It is known that a Bayesian network can be encoded into a logical formula and compiled into d-DNNF, which, if successful, allows posterior probabilities of all variables to be computed efficiently (Darwiche, 2003).

metadata.abstractText: When a system behaves abnormally, sequential diagnosis takes a sequence of measurements of the system until the faults causing the abnormality are identified, and the goal is to reduce the diagnostic cost, defined here as the number of measurements. To propose measurement points, previous work employs a heuristic based on reducing the entropy over a computed set of diagnoses. This approach generally has good performance in terms of diagnostic cost, but can fail to diagnose large systems when the set of diagnoses is too large. Focusing on a smaller set of probable diagnoses scales the approach but generally leads to increased average diagnostic costs. In this paper, we propose a new diagnostic framework employing four new techniques, which scales to much larger systems with good performance in terms of diagnostic cost. First, we propose a new heuristic for measurement point selection that can be computed efficiently, without requiring the set of diagnoses, once the system is modeled as a Bayesian network and compiled into a logical form known as d-DNNF. Second, we extend hierarchical diagnosis, a technique based on system abstraction from our previous work, to handle probabilities so that it can be applied to sequential diagnosis to allow larger systems to be diagnosed. Third, for the largest systems where even hierarchical diagnosis fails, we propose a novel method that converts the system into one that has a smaller abstraction and whose diagnoses form a superset of those of the original system; the new system can then be diagnosed and the result mapped back to the original system. Finally, we propose a novel cost estimation function which can be used to choose an abstraction of the system that is more likely to provide optimal average cost. Experiments with ISCAS-85 benchmark circuits indicate that our approach scales to all circuits in the suite except one that has a flat structure not susceptible to useful abstraction.
